identificationModule.briefTitle: Contributions to Hypertension With Androgen Deprivation Therapy
identificationModule.officialTitle: Autonomic and Renal Contributions to Hypertension With Androgen Deprivation Therapy

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This study plans to learn more about contributors to high blood pressure in men who undergo androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) to treat prostate cancer. Prostate cancer is the most common non-skin cancer in men, affecting approximately 1 in 8 American men and its primary treatment is through the use of ADT. However, ADT increases the likelihood of developing heart disease including high blood pressure. This study will determine if dysfunction of the nervous system and/or kidneys occurs in men undergoing ADT, as these systems play a significant role in control of blood pressure. The results from this study will help us understand the ways in which ADT contributes to heart disease and help us develop therapies to prevent heart disease in prostate cancer survivors.

armGroups.label: Prostate Cancer
armGroups.description: Men undergoing androgen deprivation therapy via gonadotropin releasing hormone agonist plus androgen receptor inhibitor for the treatment of prostate cancer

armGroups.label: Healthy + ADT
armGroups.description: Healthy men undergoing gonadal suppression via gonadotropin releasing hormone agonist plus androgen receptor inhibitor for 9 weeks

armGroups.label: Healthy + Placebo
armGroups.description: Healthy men undergoing placebo for 9 weeks.

primaryOutcomes.description: The change in cardiovagal baroreflex sensitivity will be assessed the modified Oxford procedure
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in blood pressure reactivity to the cold pressor test
primaryOutcomes.description: The change in blood pressure will be assessed from quiet rest to sympathetic activation using the cold pressor test
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

primaryOutcomes.description: The change in blood pressure will be assessed from quiet rest to isometric handgrip exercise
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in ambulatory blood pressure variability
primaryOutcomes.description: Ambulatory blood pressure variability will be determined from 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in beat-to-beat blood pressure variability
primaryOutcomes.description: Beat-to-beat blood pressure variability will be using finger photoplethysmography measured in the laboratory.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

primaryOutcomes.description: Renal blood flow will be determined using ultrasound and blood pressure will be determined using finger photoplethysmography. These measures will be used to estimate renal vascular resistance.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

primaryOutcomes.description: Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL), kidney injury molecule (KIM)-1, interleukin (IL)-18, and vanin-1 will be quantified in urine using commercially available assay kits. Concentrations will be normalized to urinary flow rate.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

secondaryOutcomes.description: Changes in muscle sympathetic nerve activity in response to changes in blood pressure will be assessed using the modified Oxford procedure
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

secondaryOutcomes.description: The change in muscle sympathetic nerve activity will be assessed from quiet rest to sympathetic activation using the cold pressor test.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

secondaryOutcomes.description: Glomerular filtration rate and renal plasma flow will be calculated by iohexol (Omnipaque 300, GE Healthcare) clearance technique. Plasma and urine iohexol and p-aminohippurate clearance will be measured on a High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC, Waters, Milford, MA).
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

secondaryOutcomes.description: Renal plasma flow will be calculated by p-aminohippurate (Basic Pharma) clearance techniques. Plasma and urine p-aminohippurate clearance will be measured on a High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC, Waters, Milford, MA).
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

otherOutcomes.description: Proteomic analysis of inflammatory cascade proteins will be quantified in plasma samples.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

otherOutcomes.description: Whole blood reactive oxygen species will be measured in from venous blood samples using electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

otherOutcomes.description: Descriptive variable total body fat mass (for screening and to document any changes with the intervention)
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: Before and after 9 weeks of androgen deprivation therapy or placebo

overallOfficials.name: Matthew Babcock, PhD
overallOfficials.affiliation: University of Colorado - Anschutz Medical Campus

browseBranches.name: Urinary Tract, Sexual Organs, and Pregnancy Conditions

ancestors.term: Hormones, Hormone Substitutes, and Hormone Antagonists
